change.item: Minor corrections to volunteer transcription. Recommendations to transcription changes from L. Chisholm and Ann Southwell, Manuscripts Cataloger.

div1.head:
DIARY OF CLARA SHAFER
January 1 - April 30, 1865

div3.head: n.d.
div3.p:
"Tis the work
Of many an hour, and of many a prayer
To bring the heart back from our infant gone!
Hope must give in, and busy fancy blot
Its images from all the silent rooms,
And every sight and sound familiar to her
Undo its sweetest link, and so at last,
The fountain that, once loosed, must flow forever,
Will hide, and wait in silence When the smile
Steals to her pallid lips again, and spring
Wakins its buds above thee, we will come,
And, standing by the music-haunted grave
Look in each other cheerfully, and say
A child that we have loved is gone to heaven
And by this gate of flowers she passed away."

lg.l: "Oh! the lost, still unforgotten,
Though the world be oft forgot:
Oh! the shrouded and the lonely,
In our hearts they perish not.
She sits beside the cradle.
And her beats are streaming fast,
For she sees the present only,
While she thinks of all the past;
Of the days so full of gladness
When her first-born's answering kiss
Filled her soul with such a rapture
That it knew no other bliss, O! those happy happy moments!
They but deepen her despair,
For she bends above the cradle
And her baby is not there
There are words of comfort spoken,
And the leaden clouds of grief,
Wear the smiling bow of promise.
And she feels a sad relief;
But her wavering thoughts will wander
Till they settle on the scene
Of the dark and silent chamber
And of all that might have been!
For a little vacant garment,
Or a shining tress of hair,
Tells her heart in tones of anguish
That her baby is not there —

div3.head: n.d.
div3.p:
Ye who mourn
Whene'er yon vacant cradle, or the robes
That decked the lost-one's form call back a tide
Of alienated joy, can ye not trust
Your treasure to this [-], whole changeless care
Passeth a Mother's love? Can ye not hope,
When a few wasting years their course have run
To go to him, though he no more on earth
Returns to you?

And when glad faith doth catch
Some echo of celestial harmonies,
Archangels' praises, with the high suspense
Of cherubin and seraphim, O think —
Your babe is there!

lg.l: Young Mother! what can feeble friendship say,
To soothe the anguish of this mournful day?
They, they alone, whose hearts like thine have
bled,
Know how the living mourn for the dead;
Each tutored voice that seeks such
grief to cheer,
Thinks cold upon the weeping parents care;
I've felt it all - alas! too well I know
How rain all earthly power to hush thy woe
God cheer thee childless Mother! tis not given
For man to ward the blow, that falls from
Heaven.
I've felt it all — as thou art feeling
now Like thee with stricken heart & aching brow, I've sat
and watched by dying beauty's bed, And burning tears of hopeless anquish
shed I've gazed upon the sweet-but pallid face And vainly tried some
comfort there to trace; I've listened to the short & struggling
breath; I've seen the cherub eye grow dim in death; Like thee I've
veiled my heart in speechless
gloom,
And laid my first-born in the silent
tomb.

div3.head: Friday Jan 1st. 1865
div3.p: Among the great resolutions formed to-day for the "New Year" is one to keep a "daily account of events". Thinking it may prove useful, pleasant & improving, I hope I may find myself possessed of sufficient perseverance for the task — (doubtful)

This time last week our little Millie was very ill — commenced Christmas eve! to spit blood & continued to do so for three days & nights — but to-day she is bright & apparently quite well, but confined to bed for fear of a relapse.
Tuesday last Dec 27th Sister & Temple came up to spend the remainder of the holidays
Thursday eve Maj. Page took tea with us — Yesterday (Saturday) it snowed nearly all day — This morning it is clear but very cold — & the walking such as to prevent our attending Church.

div3.head: Jan 2nd.
div3.p: Clear but very cold — Sister & Temple left for Craighton — commenced my German lessons again.

div3.head: Jan 3rd.
div3.p: Snowed nearly all day. Took no German lesson —Ma resigned the house-keeping Mr S. wrote to William.

div3.head: Jan. 4th.
div3.p: Rode into the city with Charlie The streets were so slippery that the old Grey fell on his nose once & was in constant danger of repeating the act, all the way down & back. — Mrs Yalty died this morning —

div3.head: Jan 5th.
div3.p: - Took no German lesson. Charlie commenced school with Aunty Mr. S. & Charlie spent the eve. at Capt. W.'s.

div3.head: Jan 6th.
div3.p: Rained nearly all day

div3.head: Jan 7th.
div3.p: Weather very fitful — the early morning —pleasant as spring — but before noon it rained quite heavily then snowed a little & at sunset all was clear again — Spent the day at Mrs L's — Took no German Lesson.

div3.head: Jan 8th.
div3.p: Clear but very cold — Mr S. Ma and I went to church, heard an excellent sermon from dear Mr P.{1} on the 9th V. 39th Psalm — In the eve. walked to Hollywood. Milly came down stairs to-day the first time since Christmas eve.

div3.head: Monday Jan 9th.
div3.p: Killed the calf. Mr. Angerer started for S.C. —

div3.head: Tuesday Jan 10th.
div3.p: Rained all day A visit in the eve' from Mr Holmes who gives a very gloomy account of "the times" in the country — thinks the Confederacy nearly at an end — gives it four months longer. The evacuation of R___d — & the emancipation question form the chief topics of conversation. Commenced giving Milly Cod liver Oil.

div3.head: Wednesday 11th.
div3.p: Heard from William — He sailed from N. Y. for Germany — Dec. 17th 1864. A visit in the eve' from Mrs. Fourqureau & Mrs Evins —

div3.head: Thursday 12th
div3.p: commenced knitting for the Soldiers — Opened a barrel of flour. Our old neighbor Mr. Overly & Son dined with us — Louisa sick in bed

div3.head: Friday 13th.
div3.p: Wrote to William. Millie Went to walk — Weather delightful The government was borrowing flour today from the citizens of Rd' to feed the Army!

div3.head: Saturday 14th
div3.p: Wilmington attacked by the Yankee fleet — the second time. Very cold and cloudy.

div3.head: Sunday Jan 15th.
div3.p: Aunty Mr. S. and Self went to Church — Mr. Peterkin preached from 2nd V 2nd chp 1st Cor. Found Sister & Temple at home when we returned —

div3.head: Monday Jan 16th.
div3.p: The news received of the fall of Ft. Fisher — a very serious and unexpected loss to the Confederacy — Gold selling for $70. for $1. Sister & T. left for Craighton — Had four barrels flour brought down from the Kitchen

div3.head: Tuesday 17th.
div3.p: Flour $800. for barrel! meal $100 per bushel. Bought 1 bu. turnips — 2 bu. Meal. Opened box of Soap. Cloudy — & snowing a little now and then. Mr. S. & I went to the Evins' in the eve' —

div3.head: Wednesday 18th
div3.p: Bought a pr. morocco shoes at $175. Ms Lloyd & Minnie came in the evg' —

div3.head: Thursday 19th.
div3.p: Cut Charlies's hair, Went to see Mrs. W. had a visit From Mrs. F. & H. also Mrs Ewell Mr S & I went to Mrs L's in the eve'

div3.head: Friday 20th
div3.p: Bought 1 cd, wood $120.

div3.head: Saturday 21st.
div3.p:
Weather terrible raining & freezing as fast as it falls Gold fallen to $50 for $1.2 lbs. Sugar.
bought on trial$16. per lb.

div3.head: Sunday Jan 22nd.
div3.p: Weather still very bad, the trees all ready to break with their weight of icicles — present a very beautiful appearance

div3.head: Monday Jan 23rd.
div3.p: Rained nearly all day — Mr Crouch came home from the army. Sent shoes to be mended. Made a straw hat for myself. Finished the 3rd pr socks for Soldiers.

div3.head: Tuesday 24th.
div3.p: Weather delightful but the walking very bad. Bought 2 gals. Eclactic oil $90 pr gal 4 chimneys for lamps $12-a piece Mrs Lloyd dined with us — Mr. S. & I went to Mr L's in the eve Mr S intending to call on Gen. Ewell but found the Gen & his lady there was much pleased with him — he has a noble head — fine eyes — rather sharp features — wears a moustache is very affable & amusing in con-versation — the loss of his limb is not atall perceptible until he attempts to walk — Gold $45 for $1.

div3.head: Wednesday 25th.
div3.p:
Clear but very cold Mr. Crouch dined with us. Mr Shafer Charlie & I went in the eve. to Centenary
Church to see Lieut. Wiesiger and Emma Tyler united in the holy bonds of Matrimony—

div3.head: Thursday Jan 26th
div3.p: Very cold — Walked down to Rees's Daguerrean Galery sat for my photograph Called on Mrs James but did not find her at home — Paid my first visit to Mrs Mitchel & Mrs Dr Harrison — Mrs M. was quite sick Called on Mrs Davis she was out as usual — Sent Margarette to Hills with my hat — will not be able to get it until next Friday a week

div3.head: Friday 27th
div3.p: Mr S. spent last eve' at Mr Morriss' did not get home until 2 o'clock this morn.! Last night was the coldest we have had this winter the water froze in the pitchers for the first time this Winter — Mr S — sent home ½ a beef & bushel Meal I breadfasted at 12 o'clock this morn.

div3.head: Saturday.
div3.p: The Thermometer at 10° said to be the coldest weather here since 1857. Mr Conner arrived — Mr. Evins — came a little before 9 o'clock to spend the eve'. It is reported the other peace commissioners have been sent to W—

div3.head: Sunday 29th Jan.
div3.p: It was too windy this morning to walk to Church — Mr. Thompson & I Overby spent the eve'

div3.head: Monday Jan 30th
div3.p: Spent the day with Elvira Nimmo. Mrs Cottrell & Mrs Loring Called while I was away — Mr & Mrs L & Minnie spent the eve. Got our shoes that were sent to be mended Weather delightful

div3.head: Tuesday Jan 31st
div3.p: Mr Peterkin spent the eve — with us — Aunty bought 3 lbs butter $15. per lb.

div3.head: Wednesday Feb 1st 1865
div3.p: - Weather delightful — quite Spring-like— Aunty & Mr S. wrote to William. A visit from Mrs Squire —

div3.head: Thursday. Feb 2nd
div3.p: Borrowed $50 from Ma. Called on Mrs Boidkin — Mr. S & I spent the eve. at Gen Ewell's.

div3.head: Friday Feb 3
div3.p: - Got ½ Cd. Pine Wood 2 lbs. Sugar — Mr Lloyd took supper

div3.head: Saturday Feb 4th
div3.p: Heard the sad news of Dr Conway's death — Sister & Granper {2} came out to see me — The old Gray died. Nannie Kepler & Dr. Gable called —

div3.head: Sunday Feb 5th
div3.p: Weather delightful Ma Mr S & I went to Church — Mr Peterkin preached from 7th C. 17th ve of St John. Sister Mr. C & Temple dined with us — Mr. S & I went to Mr Ritter's after tea —

div3.head: Monday. Feb 6th.
div3.p: Weather cold but clear — Aunty Mr. S & I went to poor Dr. Conway's funeral — St Paul's Church was crowded & the services were very imposing. What a loss our city has sus-tained in the death of so able a Phy-sician! Mr S. & I called on Leut Wiesiger & his bride. Mrs. L started for Sephards Town

div3.head: Tuesday Feb 7th.
div3.p: The ground covered with snow this morning — which was very unexpected as every one thought the cold weather was over — Snowed and sleeted all day —There was a fight near Petersburg to day in which Gen Pegram was killed — he was married only a few weeks since to the beautiful Miss Cary! The particulars of the fight not yet known.

div3.head: Wednesday Feb 8th.
div3.p: Weather delight-ful again — The walking dreadful. Bought 1 Lb. butter $15.

div3.head: Thursday Feb. 9th.
div3.p: Mr Angerer re-turned Aunty — received a letter from Mrs. Habard — Alice wakes early this morn — with a very _____ cough. Milly spit a little blood —

div3.head: Friday 10th.
div3.p: Mr A took breakfast with us — Aunty — bought 4 lbs — Butter $60. 3 qts wheat $15. Paid Ma $50. borrowed money. Weather very cold. Gold $60 for $1. Charlie wrote to Mr Martin —

div3.head: Saturday Feb 11th
div3.p: Mr S. sent home 2 bu. Meal 3 bu. Potatoes 6 ½ lbs butter. Aunty bought a turkey — $37. Mr Angerer took tea — sent us a nice dish of sausage & a small bag of onions — which was very acceptable as onions are $1 a piece. Sister Mr C Lucy C. & Temple called. Temple stayed all night.

div3.head: Sunday 12th.
div3.p: Too windy & muddy to go to Church — Mr Lloyd called Commenced mixing wheat with our Coffee — began on a pound of Coffee Mr Crouch took tea —

div3.head: Monday Feb 13th.
div3.p: Said to be the coldest day we have had this winter. Mr. Dabney lent us 5 bu. brown stuff Went to Mrs W.'s for a few minutes Mr. S. bought a confederate paper ½ Cord (Oak wood $64.)

div3.head: Tuesday F 14th.
div3.p: Sister went back to Craighton — Bought bag Potatoes from Dabney's — Sent Mrs Walder's dinner home — Went to Mr Lloyd's It is a week today since it snowed and there is still much of it to be seen —

div3.head: Wednesday Feb. 15th.
div3.p: It has rained nearly all day. Aunt wrote to Mrs Hubard. Mr. S complains of not feeling well. Charley was sent to bed without his supper.

div3.head: Thursday Feb. 16th.
div3.p: Weather much warmer — but still not pleasant — Traces of Snow yet to be seen. Bought 10 gals Sorghum — $70. a gal. Mr Lloyd spent the eve' —

div3.head: Friday
div3.p: - It has rained, snowed & hailed to-day — cleared off a little towards night — Mr Angerer took tea — Bought 50 lbs crushed sugar $19. per lb

div3.head: Saturday Feb. 18th.
div3.p: Clear & pleasant — Minnie Lloyd dined with us — Ma spent the morning with Mrs Evins. Aunty bought a turkey for $50. — commenced cooking in range

div3.head: Sunday Feb. 19th.
div3.p: Did not go to Church — Mr Lloyd called, Weather delightful — The bad news of the fall of Columbia was received yesterday —

div3.head: Monday Feb 20th.
div3.p: We heard to-day that Charleston was evacuated last Tuesday! South Carolina seems dormant — Weather very pleasant — Mr Lloyd & Mr Angerer took tea — Ma & I went to Mrs Walder's in the eve'—

div3.head: Tuesday Feb. 21st.
div3.p:
Moved our store-room upstairs — its contents are as follows 3 hams — 3 sides — 2 shoulders, 6 bu. meal — 55 lbs coffee — 60 lbs sugar 1 box soap 1 box onions — 5 bottles catsup — Had a visit from Mrs Wiesiger — (the bride) Mrs Tyler & Miss W — A most terrible fire took place last night — in which a family of five persons was burned
to death — Mr & Mrs Stebins b & 3 children — one a beautiful girl of 19 years — and to have been married in the Fall

div3.head: Wednesday Feb 22nd
div3.p: Washington's birth-day! & [-] poorly celebrated only the report of a few cannon to mark the great event. Elvira Nimmo called in the morning After she left I went over to Mrs Evins' — Mrs Dickenson and Mary Taylor were here when I returned Mrs Davis called before they left Gen. & Mrs Ewell came in after tea — The Gen. is very gloomy about the times — wanted to know if we had disposed of our Silver, fortunately we have not much to trouble ourselves about

div3.head: Thursday Feb 23rd.
div3.p: Has been rain-ing all-day — Browned coffee — Charlie commenced his music lessons, With Mr Angerer again — last Satur-day — took a lesson to-day —

div3.head: Friday Feb 24th
div3.p:
Brought 2 barrels of flour down from the kitchen Mr Crouch dined with us —.
Mr Angerer took tea — bought 1 lb hops $10. 3 qts — wheat-$15.

div3.head: Saturday Feb 25th.
div3.p: Rained nearly all day — Aunty went to market came home drenched — and very little in the market-basket to make up for it — two heads of cabbage for $10 — etc etc — meat $7. & $8. per lb. Bought 2 small brooms for $12. — Mr Conner paid a short visit — Charlie went to the Theatre performance commencing at 12 o'clock Mr. C took a music lesson, Finished a calico dress for Alice —

div3.head: Sunday Feb 26th.
div3.p: Rained until near church time — none of us went to church except Charlie — Aunty - & Alice went to Evening service — Mr S. had company in the afternoon

div3.head: Monday Feb. 27th
div3.p: Rained again today until afternoon — ½ Cord Wood — came. $75. Minnie Lloyd & Mr Angerer took tea — Mrs Fourqu-rean & Joseph — spent the eve

div3.head: Tuesday Feb 28th.
div3.p: Rained a little this morning cloudy all day Mr. Charlie took a music lesson Sister & Mr. Crouch took tea — Mr. C — leaves in the morning for the army.

div3.head: Wednesday - March 1st. 1864
div3.p: This is Ash Wednesday — I was sorry not to be able to attend Church. Sister & Temple spent the day went to Mrs Walder's in the eve' Mr S. spent the eve at Mr Lloyds

div3.head: Thursday March 2nd.
div3.p: Rained nearly all-day-Charles took a music lesson.

div3.head: Friday Mch. 3rd
div3.p: Rained a little again today

div3.head: Saturday March 4th
div3.p: bought 4 lbs. [-] $14. pr lb. Sister spent the day will stay until Monday. Fannie Bernard is with us tonight is looking very well — Rained very hard this morn — but cleared off beautifully about noon. Bot. 3 lbs butter

div3.head: Sunday March 5th
div3.p: Did not at-tend Church Mr. S. and Ma were there — Sister & Fannie B. kept me company at home — Mr. Conner called —

div3.head: Monday- [n.d.]
div3.p:
weather pleasant Sister left for Craigton after dinner — Mrs Mahony & Lizzie spent the morning — Mr S. & I spent the eve' at Mrs Walder's —
Received ½ cord Oak Wood.

div3.head: Tuesday March 7th
div3.p: Mr Angerer came to give C. a lesson — but he was not at home. Killed the kid. Received a letter from William dated Bremen Jan. 2nd 1865. over which we all rejoiced — it being the first we have had from him since he left home 3 months ago. Wrote to William by an opportunity offered by Minnie Lloyd.

div3.head: Wednesday- [n.d.]
div3.p: Bot. 1 bu. Blackeyed Peas Minnie helped us to make con-federate candles — Rained nearly all day —

div3.head: Thursday March 9th
div3.p: Minnie L — took tea — Rained in the eve

div3.head: Friday March 10th
div3.p: Day appropriated by President Davis — for fasting & prayer — Mr S. was at home all day spent a quiet day in our room as I was confined to bed nearly all day — Mr. S wrote my name in a set of books persenten May 1862 — Mr Gibson Mr Lloyd & Mr Harwood called in the afternnoon Mr H staid to tea — It rained -snowed & hailed during the day. Eve. clear

Bot. Cord wood — $100 -2 lbs. Butter $30 -. Received letter from L. G. in which was en-closed two letters from William to him — Heard through Mr Von Groning that William was comfor-tably settled at Dr. Fuhlraft's in Elherfeld Prussia — Fannie Bernard took tea with us will spend the night — Aunty's devoted friend and much ad-mired Dr. Benson called day before yesterday —

div3.head: Sunday March 12th
div3.p: Weather delightful Aunty & Ma went to Church. Mr Von Groning & a friend of his called just about church time Maj. Page called after dinner Had the pleasure of seeing Lieut. Benson — Fannie's beau — was much pleased with his appearance —

We were wakened last night at one o'clock by the ringing of the door bell — Mr S. enquired from the window who was there — found it was poor old Mr Duval & Son they had heard the Yankee's were very
near them — and had brought their horses
[word lined out]
and other valuables to town for protection. he went home to-day for another load — we have learned since he left that the enemy are not nearer than 30 miles — there was quite a commotion in town last night and today — bells ringing all the Departments ordered out etc etc

div3.head: Monday March 13th
div3.p: Every-thing begin-ning to look like Spring — Hyacinths and other little Spring flowers are in bloom - & the trees budding out beautifully — Fannie left this morn' Sister sent the straw for Minnie's hat —

div3.head: Tuesday March 14th
div3.p: Mr Angerer dined with us — did not give C. a music lesson — Fannie came out in the morning for a little while Aunty & Mr. S. wrote to William

div3.head: Wednesday March 15th
div3.p: — Mr. S. did not get home until quite late — was growing very uneasy when he came in — Fannie B. and Lieut. Benson took tea. Fannie stayed all night. Planted Peas.

div3.head: Thursday 16th
div3.p:
—The first violets in Bloom — Has been blowing quite a hurricane all day. Aunty Mr. S. & C —
started to a concert to night but turned back for fear of rain Mr Lloyd & Mr Evins called Had a visit this morn'. from the Rev. Mr. Ryland — Bought 3 qts Wheat $15. & 1 lb Butter $16.

div3.head: Friday March 17th.
div3.p: Planted Potatoes — Mr. S. bought a pair shoes for himself — Ma went to Church in the eve'. Weather delightful —

div3.head: Saturday March 18th
div3.p: Weather delightful — peach Apricot trees in blossom Fannie B. and her Lieut. came in the eve' — after I had retired and later Wills' & a friend came in making quite a gay party — Fannie stayed all night 4 bus meal a bag of Rice came to day

div3.head: Sunday March 19th
div3.p: Was quite sick last night — did not go to Church — Mr S. & Ma went Mr. Conner came before breakfast he - Fannie - Lieut B. & Mr Angerer dined with us — Lieut Mr A & Fannie took tea — after which they went to church — Mr S — Mr C & A went to the Mr Von Gronings after dinner —

div3.head: Monday March 20th
div3.p: - Strawberries are now in bloom — Mr S. sent home two barrels of Potatoes - bought two lbs. of tea — $100. pr lb. bought 1 lb Butter $16. the price of eggs is $25 per doz.. Mr. Colquitte sent day before yesterday 1 barrel flour Charlie brok a lamp shade — this eve.

div3.head: Tuesday March 21st
div3.p: Millie spit blood today - A cord of Wood came $180. Rained this eve. Planted Radishes

div3.head: Wednesday March 22nd.
div3.p: Elvira Nimmo called this morn' — Lousia H. has a fine son — Dr. Wellford sent his son out to see Millie — she is much better, has spit no blood since 5 o'clock this morn — Minnie Lloyd called — Fannie B & her brother took tea — F. will stay all night — Bought a lb. of butter from Mrs Walder. ½ Cord of wood came —

div3.head: Thursday March 23rd
div3.p:
175 bu.s Coal came to day — Bought 1 lb. butter at Mrs Dennis' — Mr Angerer spent the eve — Weather colder and very windy. Gave Millie the basket left for her
by her Mother — making her very happy —

div3.head: Friday March 24th
div3.p: Mrs Fourqurean called this morn — Mrs & Mr DuVal took dinner with us — took all their "plunder" home except 1 barrel flour and 1 keg of Sugar — Weather much colder — a slight fall of snow to-day
Fannie B. came to tea will stay all night — Mr S. sent home 5 gals Sorghum.

div3.head: Saturday March 25th
div3.p: Weather disagreeable — Trimmed Aunty's' bonnet. Mrs Davis called — Fannie B. here yet — Willis B. spent the eve' — Millie spit more blood to-day —
3 loads of Coal came to-day —

div3.head: Sunday March 26th
div3.p: So windy to-day none of us could venture to Church, but Mr S. — Fannie was getting uneasy about the Lieut. When he stepped in Mr. Willis, B. & Mr Lloyd were here to tea — I had the tooth ache all day. Millie has seemed better to-day. Mr Angerer called in the eve' —
Louisa sick..

div3.head: Monday March 27th
div3.p: Fannie left to-day — expects to go home to-night — Mr S. bought 5 gal.s Cerosine Oil $200. per gal. — 1 load of coal came to-day — Millie had quite a severe attack this eve' Dr. Wellford Jr came out to see her — would that I had more faith in him! Weather more pleasant to-day —

div3.head: Tuesday March 28th
div3.p: Millie has spit a good deal of blood to-day. Dr. W. Jr. came to see her this eve — ordered a mustard plaster to be applied to her chest and if she was no better - a blister — Mr. S. came home at 2½ o'clock opened the sene oil — Mrs Bos-kin called — also Mrs Erins Mrs Colquitte stopped taking milk bought 1 lb butter from Mrs Walder $20. The cherry trees are in bloom.

div3.head: Wednesday March 29th
div3.p: Millie better to-day — Mrs Dickenson call-ed & brought her a little book — Bought another lb. of butter from Mrs Walder $26. Weather pleasant

div3.head: Thursday March 30th.
div3.p: Millie spit more blood today — is better to-night Asparagus made its first appearance — Rained nearly all day — Mr Conner Mr Angerer & Dr. Harring took tea — the latter played most delightfully on the piano — we were all charmed with him —Mr C. will stay all night —

div3.head: Friday March 31st.
div3.p: Rained heavily again this morn' — but cleared away beautifully about noon Millie is better — Mr Clark took tea — he will leave for Scotland on Monday — will take letters from Aunty Mr. S. C. & A to William

div3.head: Saturday April 1st.
div3.p: Millie has been better to-day — Weather delight-ful — Maj. Page called — Minnie Lloyd took tea — Mr. L - came after tea & spent the eve' — Sister came in to-day for a little while —

div3.head: Tuesday April 4th
div3.p:
How am I to recount the events of the past two days? On Sunday morn' Aunt K. Ma & Mr S. went to church — upon their return they heard Richmond was to be evacuated that night — the report was so sudden that we could not credit it at first — we thought we would have longer notice — and when we were told the Yankees would be in town the next morn' Mr S. hooted at the idea — but soon a messenger came from the Clothing Dept. for Mr. S. to go down immediately to assist in packing goods to be sent away that night. While he was gone Willis Beman came in — all excitement — and confirmed the worst reports we had heard — then came Mr Angerer who alarmed me very much by saying all the men from the Depts would be sent away that night — so fearing Mr S. would be one of the number and that he would not be allowed time to come home — Aunt K. and Charles very bravely started down to his de-
partment about 9 o'clock at night fortunately it was bright moon-light and very mild and pleasant — but when they got to the Dept. they found Mr S. had just left for home - & that he would not have to leave the city that night — so they started home with hearts much lighter than when they left — they got home a little while before Mr S. he having stopped at a friends they described the city as being a scene of confusion — men & women hurrying to & fro & wagons & carts crowding the streets — Mr S. was considered by this time that the enemy would take possession of the city the next day — which banished sleep from our eyes — and as we had various matters to attend to, we did not retire until 4 o'clock in the morn I never spent such a night and hope never may again — Our forces we leaving the city all night the last left about day-light after setting fire to all the buildings in which tobacco was stored, several mills, magazines, etc etc — by order
it is said of Gen Ewell - So when the enemy entered the city they found many portions of it in flames — before the fire was ex-tinguished 16 squares on Main St. were containing Richmond's finest stores — all the banks — the War Dept - & the American Hotel were laid in ruins — one church also (Presbyterian) was burnt to the ground besides many private-dwellings the Arsenal of course, was fired — and one terrific explosion after an-other of shells & other amunition added tenfold to the horrors of the scene - Such was the situation of Richmond — when on Monday morning April 3rd 1865 the Yankees entered it, as its conquerors.

About 12 o'clock the Union flag was raised in Colquitts field in sight of our house — about two squares distant — and a compa-ny of sharpshooters stationed there for the day — but towards eve' — they left and the field taken possession of by a Negro Regt - with a number of covered wagons each drawn by six mules. We soon had the comfort of knowing that the enemy did not
come with the intention to plun-der and burn as we had an-ticipated — but that the strictest order was maintained, & private property respected — Mr S. and other gentle-men in the neighborhood succeed-ed in having two soldiers detailed to stand guard with them during the night — so we slept feeling perfectly secure — though surrounded by our enemy — how much more terrible was the anticipation than the reality! This morning every-thing is quiet in the city, and the Ne-gro soldiers stepping about as grandly as possible.

div3.head: Wednesday April 5th
div3.p: The white units and covered wagons of the enemy are to be seen in all directions we are anoyed by visitors in the kitchen from the Negro camp — in as much as they keep our servants from their work, but as yet they have not behaved amiss — our servants seem to look upon it as a holiday frolic — but are respectful and do what they are told with apparent willingness — but how long will this last - ?

I must say I am agreeably surprised at the manner in which every thing is conducted — so quietly & with so little pomp or parade the officers in command seem to be willing to do all in their power to secure the citizens from being molested by their soldiers — There was a paper printed in the city yesterday but we have not seen one —

Mr Lincoln honoured Richmond yesterday with his presence — returned to W- to-day — We hear rumors of a dreadful battle having been fought
but we do not know what to be-lieve — Mrs Hubard's house was again broken into last night and filled with Yankees to-day but through Aunt K-'s exertions it has been promised protection — Henry has taken possession of it to-day —
Mr S. stood guard all last night & is to be but again to night until 1 o'clock —

div3.head: Thursday - April 6th
div3.p: As yet every thing is quiet — we have a guard night & day to protect our prop-erty — while our situation is a de-plorable one still have much we have to be thankful for! —
Killed our pig today —

div3.head: Friday April 7th
div3.p: Rained a little today Mr Ritter is very sick Sister came in from Craigton with Temple — they have had a distressing time there — Mrs Christian servants refused to do any work took her mules and sold them and altogether behaved in such a way that she was afraid to stay there — This is not Good Friday!

div3.head: Saturday April 8th
div3.p: Sister & Ma went into the city this morn' to see Gen Cortz{3} as to whether he would furnish Mrs Christian with a guard and if not would he assist her in moving into the city — He was exceedingly polite — said he could not give her a guard but would send her a wagon to move into town if she found she could not stay where she is — Sister walked out to Craigton — to let Mrs C know the result of her visit — Ma came home very much pleased with Gen Cortz. Ma & Aunty went up to see Minnie Lloyd after tea they met a big darkey on the way who instead of stepping aside to let them pass — gave Aunty a nock with his elbow, and walked on — Minnie & Dr Harring came home with them — the latter cheered us with some of his delightful music. Mr S. is quite unwell tonight —

div3.head: Sunday April 9th
div3.p: Aunt K. and Ma — went to Church to-day the prayer for the President was omitted — Sister came in from Craigton to-day with her trunks Mrs C. concluded to come to town Dr Wellford was to see Mr S. Thought he would be up tomorrow Poor Mr Ritter is very ill —

div3.head: Monday April 10th
div3.p: This is Charlie birth-day — The unwelcome news of the surrender of Gen Lee's army reached us this morn' the shock was a terrible one — the only consolation is that so many preci-ous lives may be saved — the news was received here last eve and greeted by a salute of 100 guns at 9 o'clock P.M. another at 12 o'clock and another at day break — our curiosity was much excited to know what had happened but we knew it was something, we would not be to glad to hear. Our old neighbor Mr Ritter died last night after a week's illness — Mr S. is better — this eve — Mr Evins spent the eve' Rained a good deal to day —

div3.head: Tuesday April 11th
div3.p: Raining again to-day — Mr Ritter was buried at 12 o'clock — Ma Mr S. & Charlie went to his funeral. Sister went to Church with Minnie Lloyd —

div3.head: Sunday April 16th
div3.p: Every-thing has been quiet since I wrote last — Mr S. mailed a letter to-day to William — Aunty recd. a letter from Uncle Alfred the first since the war Mary left us thisyesterday morning — Mr Angerer left for parts unknown last Thursday — after selling five boxes of Tobacco belonging to Mr Shafer - and pocketing the money — there is no end to the mean things he did before he left. Rained Friday & Saturday This has been a beautiful day

div3.head: Monday April 17th
div3.p:
The shocking news of the assassination of Lincoln in the Theatre at Washington arrived here to-day — it took place Friday night he died the next day — Booth a brother
of the great tragedian is suspect-ed of being the assassin — an attempt to murder Seward was made at the same time — but it is thought he will recover from his wounds
Gen. Ripley's aid' — called to-day To know if we could let the Gen Have rooms here — "we thanked him No" — Sister has gone to Miss Temple's -— she called this eve with Bethe Wallace & Lucy Crouch

div3.head: Tuesday April 18th
div3.p: Mrs Crump & Fannie called also Minnie Lloyd — Capt Wiesiger Lieut Rice Mr Purcell & others Sister was here for a little while left Temple — Rained a little & blew a great deal —

div3.head: Wednesday April 19th
div3.p: We have our stable full of horses once more — but un-fortunately they belong to the Yankee's — and not to us. Gen Ripleys & staff have taken rooms at Mr Ritter's — have raised their flag — and have music from a band every eve.

div3.head: Thursday April 20th
div3.p: Millie spit blood to-day — had been very [-] [-] all morning — Mr. S. bought one bu meal one ham one shoulder Sold 1 bunch asparagus. 25 cts has memorable "green-back"

div3.head: Friday April 21st
div3.p: Millie rested well last night but has had several attacks to-day — Planted Potatoes — Mr Crouch arrived this eve' a paroled prisoner — Weather very warm

div3.head: Saturday April 22nd
div3.p: Dr. Wellford Jr — came out to see Millie she is better — Mr Crouch Sister & G. are here

div3.head: Sunday April 23rd
div3.p: Millie has had quite a severe attack to-day Dr Wellford Sr. came to see her — ordered a large blister — Weather quite cold again Mr. S. & I unfortunately changed our flannel shirts

div3.head: Monday. April 24th
div3.p:
Mr L set up with Millie all night she seems better Dr. W. Jr. called
Minnie Lloyd & Dr Harring were here this eve — Weather still cool. Had a visit from Mrs Harwood —

div3.head: Tuesday April 25th
div3.p: Dr. W. Jr. called. Mr. C Sister & Temple went to Craigton — Gen Rip-ley etc etc left for Manchester without many regrets —

div3.head: Wednesday April 26th
div3.p: Millie had another attack last night —

div3.head: Sunday April 30th
div3.p: Nothing of any moment having transpired I have omitted writing for the last two or three days — Millie has been improving since Wednes-day — Mr. S. renewed his allegiance to the U. S.'s last Thursday — Mrs Lloyd returned last night I long to see her. Mr Peterkin had services in his church to-day the prayer for the president of the U.S. was offered! Rained heavily last night —

note.p: [Rev. Joshua Peterkin of St. James Episcopal Church. Well known in his day.]

["General Cortz" is undoubtedly General August V. Kautz. Major-General Kautz was with the Union occupying force and had his headquarters across the street from the Governor's mansion at the corner of Governor and Ross Streets. Identification by Richmond National Battlefield Park director Robert E. L. Krick.]
